name: SHARATH KAMAL
bio: [('Beginning', 'He began playing table tennis at age four in Chennai, India, at the table tennis club where his father was a coach. He turned professional at age 16. (ttfi.org, 26 Apr 2016; indiatoday.intoday.in, 06 Aug 2009)'), ('Reason', 'His father Srinivasa Rao and uncle Muralidhara Rao were table tennis coaches. "They would probably have started coaching me before I was born if they had the chance." name: ANTHONY ARPUTHARAJ
bio: [('Beginning', 'He began playing table tennis at age seven under the guidance of his father, who also played the sport competitively. At age 10, he joined the Petroleum Sports Promotion Board [PSPB] Table Tennis Academy in Ajmer, India, to train at elite level. (ultimatetabletennis.in, 23 Aug 2017; livemint.com, 01 Feb 2012; thefangarage.com, 15 Jul 2017)'), ('Reason', '"I picked it up looking at my father, who was a table tennis player. He was my childhood coach and I owe a huge part of my success to the training given by him." (ultimatetabletennis.in, 23 Aug 2017; thehindu.com, 06 Sep 2014)'), ('Coach', 'N Ravichandran [national], IND (redbull.com, 20 Jul 2017)'), ('Ambition', 'To break into the world top 100 rankings. (timesofindia.indiatimes.com, 29 Jul 2017)'), ('Memorable', 'Beating multiple Indian national champion Sharath Kamal during the 2012 National and Inter-State Championships in Lucknow, India. (rediff.com, 07 Sep 2017)'), ('Awards', "In August 2017 he received the Arjuna Award from the Indian government's Ministry of Youth Affairs and Sports in recognition of his sporting achievements. The Arjuna Award is the highest sporting award in India. (ultimatetabletennis.in, 23 Aug 2017)In 2012 he was named Sportsperson of the Year by the Calcutta Sports Journalists' Club [CSJC]. (cricketcountry.com, 19 Apr 2012)"), ('Additional Information', "Style of playAttack (ultimatetabletennis.in, 01 Jul 2017)GeneralNATIONAL FIRSTIn April 2017 paired with Soumyajit Ghosh they became the first Indian men's doubles pair to win a title on either the ITTF Challenge Series or ITTF World Tour. They marked the achievement at the 2017 Challenge Chile Open in Santiago, Chile. (ittf.com, 30 Apr 2017)OCCUPATIONHe joined the Oil and Natural Gas Corporation of India under a sports quota programme that allows him to train and compete internationally. (sportstarlive.com, 02 Aug 2017)FAMILY TABLE TENNIS ACADEMYHis father, Arputharaj Anthony, runs the Amala Annai Table Tennis Academy for underprivileged children in Chennai, India. Amalraj and his sisters help their father to manage and run the academy. (thehindu.com, 06 Sep 2014) "), ('Hero', 'Indian table tennis player Kamlesh Mehta. (ultimatetabletennis.in, 01 Jul 2017)'), ('Relatives', 'His father, Arputharaj Anthony, played table tennis competitively. His sisters, Mary Benita and Mary Judith have played table tennis at state level in India. (thehindu.com, 06 Sep 2014)'), ('Languages', 'English, Hindi, Tamil'), ('Highlights', "RankEventYearLocationAsian Games5Team2010Guangzhou, CHNQuarterfinalTeam2014Incheon, KOR3rd RoundMen's Doubles2014Incheon, KOR3rd RoundMixed Doubles2014Incheon, KOR3rd RoundSingles2010Guangzhou, CHN1st RoundMixed Doubles2010Guangzhou, CHN1st RoundMen's Doubles2010Guangzhou, CHNWorld Championships13Team2018Halmstad, SWE25Team2016Kuala Lumpur, MAS27Team2012Dortmund, GER29Team2010Moscow, RUS33Team2014Tokyo, JPN33Team2008Guangzhou, CHN2nd RoundMixed Doubles2013Paris, FRA1st RoundMen's Doubles2011Rotterdam, NED1st RoundSingles2013Paris, FRA1st RoundMixed Doubles2011Rotterdam, NED1st RoundMixed Doubles2009Yokohama, JPNITTF World Tour3Men's Doubles2017Panagyurishte, BUL3Men's Doubles2016Panagyurishte, BULQuarterfinalMen's Doubles2017Linz, AUTQuarterfinalMen's Doubles2017New Delhi, INDQuarterfinalSingles2016Panagyurishte, BULQuarterfinalMen's Doubles2015De Haan, BEL1st RoundMen's Doubles2018Gold Coast, QLD, AUS1st RoundMen's Doubles2018Bremen, GER1st RoundMen's Doubles2017Brisbane, QLD, AUS1st RoundSingles2017Brisbane, QLD, AUS1st RoundSingles2017New Delhi, IND1st RoundSingles2015De Haan, BELAsian Championships7Team2013Busan, KOR3rd RoundSingles2013Busan, KORSouth Asian Games1Singles2016Guwahati, IND1Mixed Doubles2016Guwahati, IND1Team2016Guwahati, IND1Men's Doubles2010Dhaka, BAN1Mixed Doubles2010Dhaka, BAN2Men's Doubles2016Guwahati, IND2Singles2010Dhaka, BANCommonwealth Games1Team2018Gold Coast, QLD, AUS2Men's Doubles2014Glasgow, GBR3Team2010Delhi, INDWorld Ranking (as of 01 Aug 2018)156Singles2018")]

[('Beginning', 'She took up the sport at a young age in Meerut, India. (kreedon.com, 27 Jul 2017)'), ('Reason', 'Her brother Upendra encouraged her to take up the sport after noticing her throwing ability during a cricket match. (kreedon.com, 27 Jul 2017)'), ('Coach', 'Kashinath Naik [personal], IND (hindustantimes.com, 07 Mar 2018)'), ('Ambition', 'To break the Olympic record in javelin. (Furo Sports YouTube channel, 04 Jul 2017)'), ('Additional Information', 'GeneralNATIONAL FIRSTShe became the first Indian female javelin thrower to cross the 60m mark, when she threw 61.86m at the 2017 Federation Cup National Championships in Patiala, India. (scroll.in, 08 Jun 2017; tribuneindia.com, 28 Feb 2018)EARLY DAYSShe had trouble in her youth convincing her father to allow her to pursue her sporting ambitions. "I\'m from a village in Uttar Pradesh and my father is a farmer. He was against me becoming an athlete initially, because he believed that girls shouldn\'t play sport. I tried hard to convince him to let me play, I cried and pleaded with him. Finally, since I was the youngest at home and everyone was fond of me, he allowed it. He probably thought I\'d play a little and end up at home." (scroll.in, 08 Jun 2017) '), ('Education', 'Chaudhary Charan Singh University , Meerut, IND'), ('Languages', 'Hindi'), ('Highlights', 'RankEventYearLocationResultAsian Games3Javelin Throw2014Incheon, KOR59.53World ChampionshipsQualificationJavelin Throw2017London, GBR59.93Asian Championships3Javelin Throw2017Bhubaneswar, IND57.325Javelin Throw2015Wuhan, CHN51.267Javelin Throw2013Pune, IND52.29South Asian Games2Javelin Throw2016India57.13')]

name: Rakesh Babu
bio: [('Coach', 'Bedros Bedrosian [national], ROU (sportstarlive.com, 19 Apr 2018)'), ('Additional Information', "GeneralCOMMONWEALTH EXITHe was sent home from the 2018 Commonwealth Games in Gold Coast, QLD, Australia, after a syringe was found in his room. Although the Commonwealth Games Federation [CGF] said there was no doping offence involved, the event had a strict 'no needle' policy. His accreditation was withdrawn and the Commonwealth Games Association of India was asked to organise a flight for him to depart Australia at the earliest opportunity. name: SHABBIR
bio: [('Coach', 'Andrew Frawley [national]'), ('Training', 'thehindu.com, 05 Feb 2018'), ('Additional Information', 'GeneralNATIONAL FIRSTHe became the first Indian tenpin bowler to win an Asian championship medal when he claimed silver at the 2015 edition in Bangkok, Thailand. (thehindu.com, 01 Dec 2015; SportsDeskOnline, 2018)YOUNGEST NATIONAL CHAMPIn 2010 at age 22 he became the youngest ever national champion at the time, after winning the men\'s title at the 22nd National Championship in India. (news.indialocals.com, 22 Jun 2010; deccanherald.com, 15 Dec 2013)WORKING HARDHe is only able to dedicate a few days each week to training, because he must work to support himself financially. "Around 2013 I had to temporarily stop bowling to create my own business. I wasn\'t simply able to survive - we have to be practical, right? The things bowling taught me in life, things like discipline, hard work are something I carried on to my other professional career." [('Beginning', 'He took up the sport in 2008 in India. (Athlete, 10 Aug 2016)'), ('Reason', '"I was quite a mischievous child and always up to some trick or the other. So while my father was at work, my mother would give me all sorts of work around our wheat and rice fields. The idea was to tire me out. My parents also encouraged him in martial arts to keep me quiet." (indianexpress.com, 19 May 2016)'), ('Coach', 'Yashpal Singh Solanki [personal], IND (scroll.in, 24 Aug 2017)'), ('Ambition', 'To win a medal at the 2018 Asian Games in Indonesia. (scroll.in, 24 Aug 2017)'), ('Memorable', 'Winning the 81kg event at the 2010 Commonwealth Junior Championships in Singapore. (Athlete, 10 Aug 2016)'), ('Awards', 'In 2013 he suffered an injury to his shoulder, and required two months of recovery. (Athlete, 10 Aug 2016)'), ('Additional Information', 'Preferred techniquesUchi-mata (IJF, 17 Jul 2016)GeneralOCCUPATIONHe joined the Punjab Police in India under a sports quota programme that allows him to train and compete internationally. (scroll.in, 24 Aug 2017)FINANCIAL WORRIESHe works as an assistant sub-inspector with the Punjab Police Force and has not had the financial resources to go to many international competitions. In April 2016, he needed funds to book tickets to the Judo Grand Prix in Samsun, Turkey, so his parents decided to help. "They mortgaged their house, withdrew their life savings and gave the money to me. In other countries people played 24 to 25 events to qualify, but I knew I didn\'t have those kind of resources. I had six tournaments to prove my worth." (thehindu.com, 01 Jun 2016; sportskeeda.com, 28 May 2016; indianexpress.com, 19 May 2016)CLOSE TO QUITTINGHe almost quit the sport in 2008. "Our local coach used a lot of politics. Despite me winning every tournament, other judoka from my weight category were chosen to represent Punjab, so I wanted to quit. However, my father told me this was the true test. If I could stick with it now, I would make it. He is the one who motivated me to play." (sportskeeda.com, 28 May 2016) '), ('Hero', 'Japanese judoka Yasuhiro Yamashita. (Athlete, 10 Aug 2016)'), ('Influence', 'His parents. (Athlete, 10 Aug 2016)'), ('Education', 'Guru Nanak Dev University, Amritsar, IND'), ('Languages', 'English, Hindi'), ('Highlights', 'RankEventYearLocationOlympic Games17-90 kg2016Rio de Janeiro, BRAWorld Championships33-90 kg2017Budapest, HUNGrand Slam9-90 kg2015Abu Dhabi, UAE33-90 kg2016Baku, AZEGrand Prix9-90 kg2016Budapest, HUN9-90 kg2016Samsun, TUR17-100 kg2018Budapest, HUN17-100 kg2018Zagreb, CRO17-73 kg2015Tashkent, UZB17-90 kg2015Tashkent, UZB32-90 kg2016Almaty, KAZ33-90 kg2015Jeju, KORWorld Cup3-100 kg2018Taipei, TPE9-90 kg2015Port Louis, MRIAsian Championships5-90 kg2016Tashkent, UZB7-90 kg2017Hong Kong, CHN9-90 kg2013Bangkok, THASouth Asian Games1-90 kg2016IJF World Ranking (as of 01 Aug 2018)156-90 kg2018165-100 kg2018')]

name: BAJRANG
bio: [('Beginning', 'He began wrestling at age seven. (drilers.com, 03 Mar 2018)'), ('Reason', 'He was encouraged to take up the sport by his father Balwan Singh Punia. "In Haryana [in India], virtually every village has ample space where children play either wrestling or kabaddi on the soil. My elder brother would go to the akhaada [wrestling pit] every day and I started accompanying him. He left wrestling, but it became a daily routine for me. My father always wanted one of his sons to take up wrestling seriously, and so he encouraged me to pursue the sport." (drilers.com, 03 Mar 2018; espn.in, 19 Dec 2016)'), ('Coach', 'Jagminder Singh [national], IND; Yogeshwar Dutt [personal] IND (hindustantimes.com, 28 Apr 2018; newindianexpress.com, 28 Jan 2018)'), ('Ambition', 'To compete at the 2020 Olympic Games in Tokyo. name: Swapna
bio: [('Beginning', 'She took up heptathlon in 2014. (sportskeeda.com, 11 Jul 2017)'), ('Reason', 'Her coach recognised her potential to succeed in multiple track and field events and encouraged her to take up heptathlon. (sportskeeda.com, 11 Jul 2017)'), ('Coach', 'Subhash Sarkar [personal], IND (mykhel.com, 07 Oct 2017)'), ('Ambition', 'To break the national record of 6211 points set by JJ Shobha in 2004 and compete at the 2020 Olympic Games in Tokyo. (in.reuters.com, 31 Aug 2018)'), ('Additional Information', 'GeneralNATIONAL FIRSTShe became the first athlete representing India to win a gold medal in heptathlon at the Asian Games when she triumphed at the 2018 Games in Indonesia. (SportsDeskOnline, 31 Aug 2018; indiawest.com, 29 Aug 2018)EXTRA TOESShe was born with six toes on each foot. "I have been competing with a lot of pain physically. The width of the shoes has an impact on how my foot lands and the lack of expansion around the edges results in discomfort. I have tried multiple brands but unfortunately my condition is unique and none of the shoes are customised for something like this. Apart from the pain, of course, the shoes themselves don\'t last long." (channelnewsasia.com, 30 Aug 2018; thenewsminute.com, 04 Aug 2016) '), ('Influence', 'Coach Subhash Sarkar. (thenewsminute.com, 04 Aug 2016)'), ('Injuries', 'Despite suffering from extreme toothache that required her to apply heavy taping to her jaw and chin she won the gold medal in the heptathlon at the 2018 Asian Games in Indonesia. (bbc.co.uk, 01 Sep 2018)She struggled with back pain following the 2014 Asian Games in Incheon, Republic of Korea. The injury continued to trouble her for the next three years and she required a month-long break from training after the 2017 World Championships in London, England. (mykhel.com, 07 Oct 2017; firstpost.com, 08 Aug 2017)'), ('Education', 'Physical Education - University of Calcutta, India'), ('Languages', 'Bengali, English, Hindi'), ('Highlights', 'RankEventYearLocationResultAsian Games5Heptathlon2014Incheon, KOR5178World Championships26Heptathlon2017London, GBR5431Asian Championships1Heptathlon2017Bhubaneswar, IND5942South Asian Games2High Jump2016India1.75')]

bio: [('Beginning', 'She was introduced to the sport at age four and began playing matches at age five. (sportskeeda.com, 11 Feb 2016; tadpoles.in, 09 Sep 2013)'), ('Reason', '"My older sister used to play before I was born. She influenced me at the early stages of my career and always pushed me to work harder." (sportskeeda.com, 11 Feb 2016)'), ('Debut', '2008 for India (sportskeeda.com, 11 Feb 2016)'), ('Coach', 'Sandeep Gupta [club], IND; Soumyadeep Roy [national], IND (firstpost.com, 04 Apr 2018; scroll.in, 15 May 2018)'), ('Ambition', 'To win a medal at the 2020 Olympic Games in Tokyo. (results.gc2018.com, 04 Jul 2017)a'), ('Memorable', 'Defeating Japanese player Kasumi Ishikawa in 2011. (results.gc2018.com, 04 Jul 2017)'), ('Awards', "She was named the 2018 Table Tennis Player of the Year [People's Choice] at the Times of India Sports Award ceremony in Mumbai, India. (timesofindia.indiatimes.com, 08 Mar 2018)She won the Rajiv Gandhi State Award for sport in 2015. (ttfi.org, 16 Feb 2016)"), ('Additional Information', 'GripShakehand (ITTF, 02 Aug 2016)Style of playAttack (ITTF, 02 Aug 2016)GeneralNATIONAL FIRSTShe was a member of the Indian team that won the women\'s team event at the 2018 Commonwealth Games in Gold Coast, QLD, Australia, the first time that India had won the event at the Commonwealth Games. (timesofindia.indiatimes.com, 09 Apr 2018; SportsDeskOnline, 29 Jul 2018)EARLY DAYSAs she started getting involved in the sport, she found it tough to manage her studies, but her mother offered her support and motivated her to continue with the sport. "It was becoming difficult to manage, I was missing classes. At that time, my school and academy came forward to help me with extra classes and flexible training hours, but still something kept telling me that I need to take a call. So I sat down with my mother telling her that my mind is always on table tennis and I can\'t concentrate on studies as much as I should. It\'s a very tough decision for any child to put studies behind for sports, but my mother supported me entirely." (scroll.in, 15 May 2018) '), ('Hero', 'Indian table tennis player Sharath Kamal Achanta, Chinese table tennis player Zhang Jike, Indian cricketer Sachin Tendulkar, Russian tennis player Maria Sharapova. (firstpost.com, 28 Jul 2018; results.gc2018.com, 04 Jul 2017)'), ('Influence', 'Her mother. (results.gc2018.com, 04 Jul 2017)'), ('Relatives', 'Her sister has also played table tennis at national level in India. name: DATTU BABAN
bio: [('Beginning', 'He took up rowing in 2012 in Khadki, India. (indiatimes.com, 26 Apr 2016)'), ('Reason', 'He was introduced to rowing after joining the army despite not being able to swim. "I was scared of drowning, really scared. The guy who does not know how to swim, he is going to row a boat. I used to be so nervous. Initially my boat turned many times and I had to get across to the bank of the river along with my boat and then start again." (news18.com, 30 Apr 2016)'), ('Coach', 'Ismail Baig [national], IND; Nicolae Gioga [national], ROU (thehindu.com, 26 Jun 2018)'), ('Ambition', 'To win a medal at the 2020 Olympic Games in Tokyo. (deccanchronicle.com, 24 Aug 2016)'), ('Awards', 'In 2018 he received the Shiv Chhatrapati State Sports Award from the Government of Maharashtra in India. (hindustantimes.com, 19 Feb 2018)He was named the 2016 Rower of the Year at the Times of India Sports Awards ceremony in Mumbai, India. (timesofindia.indiatimes.com, 20 Mar 2017)'), ('Additional Information', 'GeneralOTHER STUDIESHe has also studied at the Arts, Commerce and Science College in Lasalgaon, India. (Facebook profile, 11 Jun 2018)OCCUPATIONHe joined the Indian Army under a sports quota programme that allows him to train and compete internationally. (newindianexpress.com, 14 Mar 2018)RIO MOTIVATIONHe qualified for the 2016 Olympic Games in Rio de Janeiro after finishing second in the single sculls at the 2016 Asia and Oceania Olympic qualification regatta in Chungju, Republic of Korea. This was despite his mother being in an intensive care unit with a brain injury. "In my heart of hearts I thought qualification for Rio is the best gift I could have given her and that spurred me to achieve my objective." (thehindu.com, 04 May 2016; news18.com, 30 Apr 2016)EARLY DAYSHe initially found it difficult to adjust to rowing after coming from a village where water was in short supply. "I didn\'t get the logic [of rowing]. The only thing I could think of was to take some water from the [training] centre back home. Water was very scarce in our village. We didn\'t even have water to drink. Trust me, it\'s worth more than gold. How could we imagine it could be used for sport as well?" (indiatimes.com, 26 Apr 2016) '), ('Education', 'University of Pune, India'), ('Languages', 'English, Hindi'), ('Highlights', 'RankEventYearLocationResultAsian Games5Double Sculls2014Incheon, KOR6:37.02Olympic Games13Single Sculls2016Rio de Janeiro, BRA6:54.96Asian Championships2Single Sculls2015Beijing, CHN7:18.41')]

name: ROHAN MANCHANDA
bio: [('Beginning', 'He took up tennis at age 11, and he began taking it seriously at age 19. (atpworldtour.com, 27 Jun 2016)'), ('Reason', '"Though I played cricket, hockey and football at school, individual sport fascinated me more, because I wanted to be in control of my game." (kodaguconnect.com, 19 Nov 2012)'), ('Debut', 'Turned professional in 2003'), ('Coach', 'Zeeshan Ali [national] (deccanherald.com, 04 Jun 2018)'), ('Ambition', 'To win a medal at the 2018 Asian Games in Indonesia. (timesofindia.indiatimes.com, 29 Jul 2018)'), ('Awards', 'He received the Sports Icon of the Year award at the 2018 Indian Oil Sports Conclave. (tennisworldusa.org, 10 Jun 2018)He received the Association of Tennis Professionals [ATP] Arthur Ashe Humanitarian of the Year award in 2010. (atpworldtour.com, 27 Jun 2016)He was awarded the Eklavya award by the Government of Karnataka in India in 2005 for his achievements in the field of tennis. (thenews.com.pk, 10 May 2012)'), ('Additional Information', "GeneralOCCUPATIONHe joined the Indian Oil Corporation under a sports quota programme that allows him to train and compete internationally. (tennisworldusa.org, 10 Jun 2018)BUSINESS VENTURESIn July 2018 he launched Cardio Workout, a fitness programme that combines a range of innovative tennis games and cardiovascular exercises. In January 2018 he also launched his coffee brand Rohan Bopanna's Master Blend in collaboration with coffee chain The Flying Squirrel. (cnbctv18.com, 30 Jul 2018; yourstory.com, 30 Jan 2018)TENNIS ACADEMYHe runs the Rohan Bopanna Tennis Academy in Bengaluru, India, which was started in March 2016 to promote tennis and offer coaching to young players. (rohanbopannatennis.com, 01 Apr 2018)COMMUNITY WORKAlong with Pakistani tennis player Aisam-Ul-Haq Qureshi he created the 'Stop War Start Tennis' campaign, to help victims of landmines and other weapons of war in past and present conflict zones. He has also funded a school for children with impairments in his hometown of Coorg, India and contributed to the Coorg Institute of Dental Sciences to help provide low cost dental treatment to the poor. (veethi.com, 26 Dec 2012; rio2016.com, 06 Apr 2016; atpworldtour.com, 27 Jun 2016) "), ('Hero', 'Swedish tennis player Stefan Edberg. (atpworldtour.com, 27 Jun 2016)'), ('Nickname', 'Bofors (Facebook page, 06 Jun 2016)'), ('Injuries', 'In 2018 he suffered a minor shoulder at Wimbledon and was unable to compete further at the tournament. (timesofindia.indiatimes.com, 29 Jul 2018)In 2009 he was sidelined by a knee injury for three months. (newindianexpress.com, 13 Jan 2010)'), ('Languages', 'English, Hindi'), ('Hobbies', 'Listenign to music, watching movies, cars, bikes. name: Aruna
bio: [('Beginning', 'She took up gymnastics at age eight. (deccanchronicle.com, 20 Jun 2014)'), ('Reason', 'She got involved in karate at age five but at age eight her karate master realised that her body was flexible and encouraged her to try gymnastics. (deccanchronicle.com, 20 Jun 2014)'), ('Coach', 'Brij Kishore [personal], from 2008 (indiatimes.com, 24 Feb 2018)'), ('Ambition', 'To compete at the 2018 Commonwealth Games in Gold Coast, QLD, Australia, and the 2020 Olympic Games in Tokyo. (telanganatoday.com, 08 Feb 2017)'), ('Additional Information', 'GeneralNATIONAL FIRSTShe became the first Indian gymnast to finish on the podium at a World Cup event when she placed third in women\'s vault in 2018 in Melbourne, VIC, Australia. (fig-gymnastics.com, 26 Feb 2018)COMMONWEALTH COMEBACK She competed at the 2014 Commonwealth Games in Glasgow, Scotland, four years after being ineligible to compete at the 2010 Commonwealth Games in Delhi, India, because she was too young. "I wanted to be part of the Commonwealth Games in 2010, I had even qualified, but because I was underage [age 14], I couldn\'t take part. Right after that I started training for the next Commonwealth Games." (deccanchronicle.com, 20 Jun 2014)SUPPORTHer father Narayan Reddy sold his house to help her become a gymnast. However, he passed away in 2012. She competed at the 2012 Senior National Championships in Udaipur, India, a few months after, winning gold in vault and beam. "I told my father that since he had sacrificed so much for my training, I was not going to settle for anything less than a gold. After my father\'s death, I lost my focus for a week or so. I didn\'t know what to do and even contemplated quitting the sport. But my sister and brother-in-law took care of me and provided me the support which I needed then." (dnaindia.com, 18 Apr 2012) '), ('Influence', 'Her father. (deccanchronicle.com, 15 Feb 2017)'), ('Education', 'Osmania University, Hyderabad, IND'), ('Languages', 'Hindi, Telugu, English'), ('Highlights', 'RankEventYearLocationResultAsian Games8Team2014Incheon, KOR179.6259Vault2014Incheon, KOR13.37536Individual All-Around2014Incheon, KOR43.15039Floor Exercise2014Incheon, KOR11.30044Balance Beam2014Incheon, KOR10.60046Uneven Bars2014Incheon, KOR7.650World Championships24Vault2014Nanning, CHN13.04926Vault2017Montreal, QC, CAN13.16638Team2014Nanning, CHN166.87845Vault2013Antwerp, BEL12.83369Individual All-Around2017Montreal, QC, CAN42.86596Floor Exercise2013Antwerp, BEL10.93399Floor Exercise2017Montreal, QC, CAN10.66699Uneven Bars2017Montreal, QC, CAN9.733108Balance Beam2017Montreal, QC, CAN9.033108Balance Beam2013Antwerp, BEL9.433155Individual All-Around2014Nanning, CHN42.515191Floor Exercise2014Nanning, CHN11.016195Balance Beam2014Nanning, CHN10.833210Uneven Bars2014Nanning, CHN7.233World Cup3Vault2017/2018Melbourne, VIC, AUS13.6497Floor Exercise2017/2018Melbourne, VIC, AUS10.83311Balance Beam2017/2018Melbourne, VIC, AUS9.966Asian Championships6Vault2017Bangkok, THA12.8256Team2017Bangkok, THA136.20018Floor Exercise2017Bangkok, THA11.65025Individual All-Around2017Bangkok, THA43.40033Uneven Bars2017Bangkok, THA8.75036Balance Beam2017Bangkok, THA9.500Commonwealth Games7Team2018Gold Coast, QLD, AUS128.97511Vault2018Gold Coast, QLD, AUS13.20014Individual All-Around2018Gold Coast, QLD, AUS44.40029Balance Beam2018Gold Coast, QLD, AUS10.15030Floor Exercise2018Gold Coast, QLD, AUS10.35030Uneven Bars2018Gold Coast, QLD, AUS9.800World Ranking List (as of 14 Apr 2018)14Vault2017/20182040Floor Exercise2017/20181256Balance Beam2017/20187')]

name: Dutee
bio: [('Beginning', 'She took up athletics at age four in Odisha, India. (smh.com.au, 15 Jul 2016)'), ('Reason', 'She was inspired to take up athletics by her elder sister Saraswati Chand. (newindianexpress.com, 13 Jul 2016; thequint.com, 14 Jul 2016)'), ('Coach', 'Nagapuri Ramesh [national], IND (hindustantimes.com, 26 Apr 2018)'), ('Ambition', 'To win a medal at the Olympic Games, and to compete at the 2022 Commonwealth Games in Birmingham, England. (bbc.co.uk, 27 Apr 2018)'), ('Additional Information', 'GeneralHYPERANDROGENISM REGULATIONSIn 2014 she was banned for 18 months by the International Association of Athletics Federations [IAAF] after she was found to have excess levels of androgen in her body. The high levels were the result of hyperandrogenism, a condition where women have higher than average testosterone levels. She appealed the ban to the Court of Arbitration for Sport [CAS] who ruled in her favour in July 2015 and overturned the ban. In January 2018 the IAAF submitted revised hyperandrogenism regulations to CAS that were accepted, and which no longer covered events in which Chand intended to compete. "The rule is very wrong. Hyperandrogenism is natural, god-given. We were born this way, we have not done anything to our body to change it. So what can we do about it? How can we change it? The new rule is for the 400m and 800m events, and my events are 100m and 200m, so I will not be affected by the rule, but there are others like Caster Semenya who will be affected. I am very saddened by this." (thehindu.com, 17 Jul 2014; bbc.co.uk, 07 Oct 2014, 27 Apr 2018; hindustantimes.com, 26 Apr 2018; thenewsminute.com, 28 Apr 2018; tas-cas.org, 19 Jan 2018)OLYMPIC RETURNAt the 2016 Olympic Games in Rio de Janeiro she became the first Indian female athlete in 36 years to compete in the 100m at the Olympic Games. To commemorate the achievement Indian businessman Anand Mahindra promised to give her a car as a gift regardless of her performance after he read about the athlete\'s intention to buy a new car. (indianexpress.com, 11 Jul 2016; thequint.com, 14 Jul 2016; timesofindia.indiatimes.com, 02 Aug 2016) '), ('Influence', 'Her family and coach. (hindi.news18.com, 31 Aug 2018)'), ('Relatives', 'Her sister Saraswati Chand was a state-level runner. (thequint.com, 14 Jul 2016)'), ('Nickname', 'Nano [after the car she received as a gift for winning the school nationals] (firstpost.com, 11 Jul 2016)'), ('Injuries', 'Her training was disrupted due to a hamstring injury in April 2018. (espn.co.uk, 28 Apr 2018)She missed two weeks of training with a fractured wrist in January 2018. (indianexpress.com, 20 Jan 2018)'), ('Education', 'KIIT University, Bhubaneswar, IND'), ('Languages', 'Bengali, English, Hindi, Oriya'), ('Highlights', 'RankEventYearLocationResultOlympic GamesRound 1100m2016Rio de Janeiro, BRA11.69World ChampionshipsHeats100m2017London, GBR12.07Asian Championships3100m2017Bhubaneswar, IND11.5234 x 100m Relay2017Bhubaneswar, IND44.573200m2013Pune, IND23.824200m2017Bhubaneswar, IND23.5944 x 100m Relay2015Wuhan, CHN45.72South Asian Games2200m2016India24.1424 x 100m Relay2016India45.793100m2016India11.75')]

name: RAJAT
bio: [('Beginning', 'He took up archery in 2007 in Jaipur, India. (indianwomenblog.org, 19 Sep 2016)'), ('Reason', '"Initially my inclination towards sports was majorly because I could bunk classes, and even my family didn\'t mind my low scores in academics as they knew I was focusing on my game. I remember how I chose archery. My elder brother had given me a few options, but I couldn\'t make up my mind. So, I just went to Sawai Mansingh Stadium with a friend on his bike. We entered from the Tonk Road side, and the first ground I saw was for archery so I took it as a God\'s sign." (indianwomenblog.org, 19 Sep 2016)'), ('Debut', '2011 for India (indianexpress.com, 05 Aug 2015)'), ('Coach', 'Jiwanjot Singh Teja [national], IND; Dhaneshwar Maida [national], IND (sportsauthorityofindia.nic.in, 11 Apr 2018)'), ('Ambition', 'To compete at the 2018 Asian Games in Indonesia. (patrika.com, 01 Nov 2017)'), ('Awards', "In 2016 he received the Arjuna Award from the Ministry of Youth Affairs and Sports in India. (Facebook page, 27 Apr 2018; dnaindia.com, 22 Aug 2016)He received the World Archery Federation's Purple and Gold Target awards in 2013. (starlive24.in, 20 Dec 2013)"), ('Additional Information', 'GeneralNATIONAL FIRSTSAfter winning gold in the men\'s team compound event at the 2014 Asian Games in Incheon, Republic of Korea, he and teammates Abhishek Verma and Sandeep Kumar became the first Indian archers to win a gold medal at the Asian Games. He also became the first Indian archer to win an individual medal at the world championships, following his silver medal in the men\'s compound event at the 2015 edition in Copenhagen, Denmark. (timesofindia.indiatimes.com, 27 Sep 2014; indianwomenblog.org, 19 Sep 2016; indianexpress.com, 05 Aug 2015; SportsDeskOnline, 27 Jun 2018)EARLY DAYSAs a child his mother Nirmala Chauhan raised two lakh of Indian rupees by selling gold ornaments to buy him an imported archery kit from the United States of America. "Gold bangles are nothing before my son\'s dream and achievements. All I want is him to do his country proud," she said. (Youtube.com, 25 Feb 2012; kridangan.com, 08 Oct 2013) '), ('Influence', 'His parents. (indianexpress.com, 05 Aug 2015)'), ('Education', 'University of Rajasthan, Jaipur, IND'), ('Languages', 'Hindi'), ('Highlights', "RankEventYearLocationAsian Games1Compound Men's Team2014Incheon, KOR36Compound Individual2014Incheon, KORWorld Games17Compound Individual2013Cali, COLWorld Championships2Compound Individual2015Copenhagen, DEN8Compound Men's Team2015Copenhagen, DEN8Compound Individual2013Antalya, TUR9Compound Men's Team2013Antalya, TURWorld Cup9Compound Mixed Team2016Antalya, TUR9Compound Individual2015Wroclaw, POL9Compound Individual2015Shanghai, CHN17Compound Individual2018Shanghai, CHN17Compound Individual2015Antalya, TUR33Compound Individual2018Antalya, TUR33Compound Individual2016Antalya, TUR57Compound Individual2018Berlin, GERAsian Championships1Compound Individual2015Bangkok, THA1Compound Men's Team2015Bangkok, THA2Compound Men's Team2017Dhaka, BAN5Compound Individual2017Dhaka, BAN5Compound Individual2013Taipei, TPESouth Asian Games1Compound Individual2016India1Compound Men's Team2016IndiaWorld Ranking (as of 01 Aug 2018)61Compound Individual2018")]

name: JOSHANA
bio: [('Beginning', 'She began the sport at age seven. (mapsofindia.com, 03 Feb 2014)'), ('Reason', 'Her father motivated her to take up squash. "He is my inspiration and he introduced me to the sport when I was a kid at the Madras Cricket Club. I owe taking the sport up seriously to him." (thebridge.in, 24 Mar 2018)'), ('Coach', 'Cyrus Poncha [national], IND (dnaindia.com, 17 Apr 2018)'), ('Ambition', 'To compete at the 2018 Asian Games in Indonesia. (zeenews.india.com, 17 Apr 2018)'), ('Memorable', 'Placing first at the 2017 Asian Squash Championship in Chennai, India. (scroll.in, 01 May 2017)'), ('Awards', "In 2018 she received the Asian Squash Federation's Dato Alex Lee Award for outstanding performance in the senior women's category. (timesofindia.indiatimes.com, 20 Mar 2018)In February 2018 she was presented with the Sports Achiever Award by the Rotary Club of Madras in Chennai, India. (thehindu.com, 06 Feb 2018)In 2013 she received the Arjuna Award from the Indian government. (mid-day.com, 31 Aug 2013)"), ('Additional Information', 'GeneralNATIONAL FIRSTSShe became the first Indian player to win an Asian championship title when she claimed victory at the 2017 edition of the tournament in Chennai, India. In 2014 she and Dipilka Karthik became the first Indian squash players to win gold at the Commonwealth Games when they triumphed in doubles in Glasgow, Scotland. (hindustantimes.com, 30 Apr 2017; thebridge.in, 24 Mar 2018; SportsDeskOnline, 13 Jun 2018)CAREER CHANGING INJURYThe knee injury she suffered in 2011 changed her outlook on the sport. "I feel the knee surgery was the best thing that could have happened to me. It changed everything about my life, whether it was the company I kept or the way I approached my game. It was like starting my career from scratch after being on the couch for six months". (asianage.com, 28 Apr 2014) '), ('Hero', 'US basketball player Michael Jordan, Indian sprinter PT Usha. (wispa.net, 07 Jun 2007; sports.indiainfo.com, 22 Nov 2009)'), ('Relatives', 'Her family has been playing squash for the previous four generations. Her great-grandfather Field Marshall KM Cariappa, who was also the first Commander-in-Chief of the Indian Army, was a regular player of squash, and her father Anjan Chinappa also played squash regularly and represented Tamil Nadu several times. (mapsofindia.com, 03 Feb 2014)'), ('Injuries', 'She suffered a serious knee injury in 2011 that required surgery. The injury kept her out of action for six months. (asianage.com, 28 Apr 2014)'), ('Education', 'English - Ethiraj College, India'), ('Languages', 'English, Hindi'), ('Highlights', 'RankEventYearLocationAsian Games2Team2014Incheon, KOR3Team2010Guangzhou, CHN5Singles2014Incheon, KOR5Singles2010Guangzhou, CHN5Singles2006Doha, QAT5Singles2002Busan, KORWorld Games9Singles2013Cali, COLWorld Championships5Singles2016El Gouna, EGY9Singles2015Kuala Lumpur, MAS9Singles2014Cairo, EGY17Singles2017Manchester, GBR17Singles2013George Town, MAS17Singles2009Amsterdam, NEDWorld Team Championships5Team2012Nimes, FRA9Team2016Paris, FRA14Team2014Niagara-on-the-Lake, ON, CANWorld Doubles Championships3Doubles W2017Wroclaw, POL3Doubles W2016Darwin, NT, AUS3Doubles X2016Darwin, NT, AUS7Doubles X2017Wroclaw, POL7Doubles X2004Chennai, INDAsian Individual Championships1Singles2017Chennai, IND2Team2010Chennai, IND3Singles2015Kuwait City, KUW3Singles2008KuwaitSouth Asian Games1Singles2016Guwahati, IND1Team2016Guwahati, IND1Singles2006Colombo, SRI1Singles2004Islamabad, PAKCommonwealth Games1Doubles W2014Glasgow, GBR2Doubles W2018Gold Coast, QLD, AUS5Singles2018Gold Coast, QLD, AUS5Doubles X2018Gold Coast, QLD, AUSWorld Ranking (as of 01 Aug 2018)16Singles2018')]

name: DEBORAH
bio: [('Beginning', 'She took up the sport at an early age and began receiving formal training at the Sports Authority of India training centre in Port Blair, India. (reuters.com, 19 Aug 2018)'), ('Reason', 'She developed a love for cycling after taking a ride on her cousin\'s bike. "Then came a cycling competition and I asked dad if I could use his cycle. He let me use it, but I had to promise to him that I\'d win, which I did." (reuters.com, 19 Aug 2018)'), ('Training', 'She trains at the Indira Gandhi Sports Complex in New Delhi, India. (indianexpress.com, 01 Apr 2018)'), ('Ambition', 'To win a medal at the Olympic Games. (reuters.com, 19 Aug 2018)'), ('Additional Information', 'GeneralTSUNAMI SURVIVORIn 2004, when she was age nine, a tsunami struck the Nicobar Islands in India, displacing her family and destroying her home. She survived by climbing up a tree and was reunited with her family five days later. "I was probably nine then. [My mother] screamed \'Get up and run fast\', and so we did. We ran out and reached a field. Our village was pretty close to the sea and the sea was roaring. I was holding mom\'s hand but suddenly I found myself engulfed by water. Even mom didn\'t realise when we split. I spent five days perched on the tree. Maybe longer, but the trauma had dulled my senses. I just cried and cried. I had mosquito bites all over my body and I grew so weak. They [a search party] got me down. I had given up hope of seeing my family again. My parents feared I had been swept away. When we finally reunited, you can imagine how much I cried." (reuters.com, 19 Aug 2018)OCCUPATIONShe works for the Andaman and Nicobar Police service in India. (kreedon.com, 11 Nov 2017) '), ('Hero', 'Indian boxer Mary Kom, Indian artistic gymnast Dipa Karmakar. (reuters.com, 19 Aug 2018)'), ('Relatives', 'Her brother Appolonious represented India in track cycling at the 2017 Asian Indoor and Martial Arts Games in Ashgabat, Turkmenistan, and the 2018 Asian Games in Indonesia. (SportsDeskOnline, 31 Aug 2018; sportstarlive.com, 04 Jul 2018)'), ('Education', 'Jawaharlal Nehru Rajkeeya Mahavidyalaya, India'), ('Languages', 'English, Hindi'), ('Highlights', name: HARMEET RAJUL
bio: [('Beginning', 'He began playing the sport at age six with his older brother, under the guidance of their father, who was their first coach. "I was six years old, my father played table tennis at his university. He bought a table tennis board home. I loved to play on that when I was little, I always wanted to play." (idrottonline.se, 10 Dec 2013)'), ('Reason', 'The influence of his father and older brother drove him to compete at the highest level. "It was love at first site with table tennis for me. I couldn\'t imagine my life without it. It was my decision at the age of 6-7 to take it up seriously. My parents also have a really big role to play in where I am today. They always supported me and encouraged me to follow my heart. The game has helped me in more ways than one. It has given me the opportunity to make my country proud, it has helped me to be a better human being, and I have travelled to more than 40 countries to represent India." (idrottonline.se, 2013; We Love Surat Youtube Channel, 23 Jul 2016; thesportsrush.com, 15 Jul 2017)'), ('Coach', 'Peter Karlsson [personal], SWE; Hraday Desai [brother], IND (ittf.com, 04 May 2017)'), ('Ambition', 'To win a medal at the Commonwealth Games and Asian Games. (thesportsrush.com, 15 Jul 2017)'), ('Memorable', 'His performance at the 2015 Commonwealth Table Tennis Championships in Surat, India, where he won two gold medals. (thesportsrush.com, 15 Jul 2017)'), ('Awards', 'In 2016 he received the Khel Pratibha Purshkar Award from the Gujarat State Table Tennis Association in India, for his performances at the 2015 Commonwealth Table Tennis Championships in Surat, India. (gstta.in, 01 Feb 2016)He won the 2015 Shaktidoot Award from the Sports Authority of Gujarat for his performances in international tournaments that year. (gstta.in, 01 Feb 2016)In 2015 he received the Sardar Patel Award from the Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel Foundation in India, for his sporting contributions. (ahmedabadmirror.indiatimes.com, 19 Aug 2015)'), ('Additional Information', "Style of playAttack (ultimatetabletennis.in, 01 July 2017)GeneralPLAYING IN EUROPEIn 2010 he moved from India to Sweden after receiving a scholarship to train at Peter Karlsson's table tennis academy as part of the Olympic Solidarity Programme. (kheldemo.cybersurf.in, 17 Sep 2013; idrottonline.se, 2013; Facebook profile, 15 Apr 2014)NATIONAL FIRSTIn June 2012 he won gold in the U21 men's final of the Brazil Open Table Tennis event in Santos, becoming the first Indian player to win gold in the event. (timesofindia.indiatimes.com, 17 Jun 2012)OCCUPATIONHe works for the Oil and Natural Gas Corporation of India. (Facebook profile, 15 Jul 2017) "), ('Hero', 'Spanish tennis player Rafael Nadal. (ultimatetabletennis.in, 01 Jul 2017)'), ('Education', 'Business Administration'), ('Languages', 'Bengali, English, Gujarati, Hindi'), ('Hobbies', 'Reading biographies of famous athletes, movies and games, travelling. (Facebook profile, 15 Apr 2014; idrottonline.se, 2013)'), ('Highlights', "RankEventYearLocationAsian GamesQuarterfinalTeam2014Incheon, KOR3rd RoundMen's Doubles2014Incheon, KORWorld Championships13Team2018Halmstad, SWE25Team2016Kuala Lumpur, MAS33Team2014Tokyo, JPN2nd RoundMixed Doubles2017Dusseldorf, GER2nd RoundMen's Doubles2017Dusseldorf, GER1st RoundSingles2017Dusseldorf, GERITTF World Tour2Men's Doubles2015Sydney, NSW, AUS3Men's Doubles2015Subic Bay, PHIQuarterfinalMen's Doubles2017Stockholm, SWE3rd RoundSingles2016Panagyurishte, BUL2nd RoundSingles2017New Delhi, IND2nd RoundSingles2015Sydney, NSW, AUS2nd RoundSingles2015Subic Bay, PHI2nd RoundSingles2016Stockholm, SWE2nd RoundSingles2016Olomouc, CZE1st RoundMen's Doubles2018Gold Coast, QLD, AUS1st RoundMen's Doubles2018Hong Kong, CHN1st RoundMen's Doubles2017Panagyurishte, BUL1st RoundMen's Doubles2017Brisbane, QLD, AUS1st RoundMen's Doubles2017New Delhi, IND1st RoundMen's Doubles2016Incheon, KOR1st RoundSingles2017Panagyurishte, BUL1st RoundSingles2017Brisbane, QLD, AUS1st RoundSingles2015Wels, AUTAsian Championships7Team2013Busan, KOR8Team2017Wuxi, CHN8Team2015Bangkok, THAQuarterfinalMen's Doubles2015Bangkok, THA3rd RoundMen's Doubles2017Wuxi, CHN3rd RoundSingles2017Wuxi, CHN3rd RoundSingles2013Busan, KOR3rd RoundSingles2015Bangkok, THA2nd RoundMixed Doubles2017Wuxi, CHN2nd RoundMen's Doubles2013Busan, KORCommonwealth Games1Team2018Gold Coast, QLD, AUS3Men's Doubles2018Gold Coast, QLD, AUSLast 32Mixed Doubles2018Gold Coast, QLD, AUSQuarterfinalSingles2018Gold Coast, QLD, AUSWorld Ranking (as of 01 Aug 2018)99Singles2018")]

name: POOJA
bio: [('Beginning', 'She first tried wrestling at age 16. (indiatoday.in, 13 Feb 2018; yourstory.com, 18 Jan 2018)'), ('Reason', 'Previously an international judoka, her coach Kripa Shankar Bishnoi motivated her to take up wrestling. "Since childhood, I wanted to be a wrestler but because of my age I took up judo in 2007 and won medals for the country. But later, when I was 16, I was advised to choose one sport and I joined wrestling." (indiatoday.in, 13 Feb 2018; yourstory.com, 18 Jan 2018)'), ('Coach', 'Kuldeep Singh, IND (indianexpress.com, 06 Feb 2018)'), ('Ambition', 'To win a medal at the Olympic Games. (thequint.com, 04 Apr 2018)'), ('Additional Information', 'GeneralHISTORIC ACHIEVEMENTShe became the first Indian athlete from any sport to win a medal at a Youth Olympic Games when she claimed silver in the 60kg category at the inaugural Games in Singapore in 2010. She reached the final without conceding a point, before losing to Baatarzorig Battsetseg of Mongolia in the final. (SportsDeskOnline, 28 Jul 2018; deccanherald.com, 16 Aug 2014) '), ('Hero', 'Her father Ajmer Singh Dhanda. name: SATHIYAN
bio: [('Beginning', 'He began the sport at age five at a neighbourhood table tennis academy in Chennai, India, where a coach noticed his talent and encouraged him to enrol in the academy. At age seven he started competing at state level, and by age 12 he was competing at national level. (educationtimes.com, 31 Jul 2017)'), ('Reason', 'He was always passionate about the sport, but did not concentrate on it full-time until after he graduated from university. "There was a point in life when I was in a dilemma. I had to make a decision between education and table tennis. Table tennis has always been my first love. I had an immense passion for it, though I had a liking for science and computers too. When I was doing both at the same time [at university], that was when I realised that I should take up the sport as my profession, as that was the only thing which made me feel complete." (thefield.scroll.in, 23 Jul 2017; sportskeeda.com, 05 Sep 2017)'), ('Coach', 'N Ravichandran [club], IND; Massimo Costantini [national], ITA; Subramaniam Raman [personal], IND, from 2013 (ittf.com, 06 Jan 2018, 12 Jun 2017, 03 Sep 2017)'), ('Ambition', 'To win a team medal at the Olympic Games. (newsclick.in, 25 Apr 2018)'), ('Memorable', "Winning the men's singles title at the 2016 Belgium Open. (sportskeeda.com, 31 May 2017)"), ('Additional Information', 'GripShakehand (ultimatetabletennis.in, 01 Jul 2017)Style of playAttack (ultimatetabletennis.in, 01 Jul 2017)GeneralBALANCING SPORT AND STUDYHe grew up in a family where the traditional focus was on education rather than sport. He says it was difficult balancing his university degree in engineering with his training, and he would often compete at tournaments on just a few hours sleep due to his study commitments. After he graduated in 2014, he decided to dedicate himself to table tennis full-time. "The only reason I completed my engineering degree was because I wanted to get it out of the way. My dream is and always will be to be the world\'s best table tennis player, but every athlete who wants to represent their country needs to make sacrifices. This was mine, I needed to prove to my family that I\'m strong enough to do both." (ittf.com, 26 Sep 2016; thefield.scroll.in, 23 Jul 2017; sportskeeda.com, 05 Sep 2017)OCCUPATIONHe works as a human resources executive for the Oil and Natural Gas Corporation of India [ONGC], as part of a sports quota programme that allows him to train and compete internationally. (Facebook page, 04 Nov 2017; Facebook profile, 15 Oct 2017) '), ('Influence', 'Indian table tennis player Sharath Kamal Achanta. (timesofindia.indiatimes.com, 27 Jul 2017)'), ('Education', "Engineering - St. Joseph's College of Engineering, Chennai, IND"), ('Languages', 'English, Hindi, Tamil'), ('Highlights', "RankEventYearLocationWorld Championships13Team2018Halmstad, SWE25Team2016Kuala Lumpur, MAS2nd RoundMen's Doubles2017Dusseldorf, GER2nd RoundMixed Doubles2017Dusseldorf, GER2nd RoundSingles2015Suzhou, CHN1st RoundMen's Doubles2015Suzhou, CHN1st RoundSingles2017Dusseldorf, GERITTF World Tour1Singles2016De Haan, BEL2Men's Doubles2017Panagyurishte, BUL3Men's Doubles2017Stockholm, SWE3Men's Doubles2016Panagyurishte, BULQuarterfinalMen's Doubles2018Gold Coast, QLD, AUSQuarterfinalMen's Doubles2018Doha, QATQuarterfinalMen's Doubles2017Linz, AUTQuarterfinalMen's Doubles2017Brisbane, QLD, AUSQuarterfinalMen's Doubles2017New Delhi, INDQuarterfinalSingles2016Panagyurishte, BULQuarterfinalMen's Doubles2016De Haan, BELQuarterfinalMen's Doubles2015De Haan, BEL2nd RoundSingles2018Gold Coast, QLD, AUS2nd RoundSingles2018Doha, QAT2nd RoundSingles2017Brisbane, QLD, AUS1st RoundMen's Doubles2018Budapest, HUN1st RoundMen's Doubles2016Stockholm, SWE1st RoundMen's Doubles2016Incheon, KOR1st RoundMen's Doubles2016Otocec, SLO1st RoundSingles2018Incheon, KOR1st RoundSingles2018Hong Kong, CHN1st RoundSingles2017New Delhi, IND1st RoundSingles2016Stockholm, SWE1st RoundSingles2016Olomouc, CZE1st RoundSingles2016Otocec, SLO1st RoundSingles2016Budapest, HUN1st RoundSingles2015Stockholm, SWE1st RoundSingles2015De Haan, BELAsian Championships8Team2017Wuxi, CHN8Team2015Bangkok, THA4th RoundSingles2015Bangkok, THA3rd RoundMen's Doubles2015Bangkok, THA2nd RoundSingles2017Wuxi, CHNSouth Asian Games1Men's Doubles2016Guwahati, IND1Team2016Guwahati, IND2Singles2016Guwahati, IND2Mixed Doubles2016Guwahati, INDCommonwealth Games1Team2018Gold Coast, QLD, AUS2Men's Doubles2018Gold Coast, QLD, AUS3Mixed Doubles2018Gold Coast, QLD, AUSQuarterfinalSingles2018Gold Coast, QLD, AUSWorld Ranking (as of 01 Aug 2018)39Singles2018")]

name: Lakshmanan
bio: [('Beginning', 'He took up athletics at age 14 at the Kavinadu Youth Sports Club in Pudukkottai, India. He began training in distance running at age 16 . (timesofindia.indiatimes.com, 07 Jul 2017; espn.co.uk, 02 Jun 2017)'), ('Reason', '"I was never interested in running initially and my father never forced me. But when I turned 14, I grew interested. Because Suriya [the daughter of his adoptive father] was always at the track, I too wanted to go." (espn.co.uk, 02 Jun 2017)'), ('Coach', 'Surendra Singh, IND (theweek.in, 30 Dec 2017; thehindu.com, 11 Jul 2017)'), ('Training', 'He trains at the Army Sports Institute in Pune, India. He runs between 170 and 180 kilometres a week. (theweek.in, 30 Dec 2017; thehindu.com, 11 Jul 2017)'), ('Memorable', 'Competing against British athlete Mo Farah in the heats of the 5000m at the 2017 World Championships in London, England. (indianexpress.com, 11 Aug 2017; outlookindia.com, 10 Aug 2017)'), ('Additional Information', 'GeneralUPBRINGINGHe was adopted by his neighbour S. Loganathan at age six after his father passed away in a car accident. "I have two fathers - my birth father Govindan and Loganathan sir. As far as I remember he was my father." (espn.co.uk, 02 Jun 2017; thehindu.com, 11 Jul 2017)FAMILY AFFAIRHis adoptive sister Suriya has also represented India in the sport. Although she has been running most of her life, Govindan only became interested in the sport at about age 14 because Suriya was always at the track. The two now spend a significant amount of time together at national training camps, and both say they find being around a sibling is helpful. "A lot of the campers have told me that when they see us fight and joke with each other, they tell me how much they miss their own brothers. A lot of them are lonely so it makes me appreciate how special it is to have my brother in the national camp with me," Suriya said. (espn.co.uk, 02 Jun 2017) '), ('Hero', 'British distance runner Mo Farah, Ethiopian distance runner Kenenisa Bekele. (indianexpress.com, 11 Aug 2017; outlookindia.com, 10 Aug 2017; thehindu.com, 11 Jul 2017)'), ('Relatives', "His adoptive father S. Loganathan was a distance runner and is founder of the Kavinadu Youth Sports Club in Pudukkottai, India. Loganathan's daughter Suriya [who Govindan calls his sister] has also represented India in athletics, competing in the 10,000m at the 2018 Commonwealth Games in Gold Coast, QLD, Australia. (SportsDeskOnline, 05 Jun 2018; newindianexpress.com, 17 Jul 2017; espn.co.uk, 02 Jun 2017; hindustantimes.com, 18 Feb 2016)"), ('Nickname', 'G (Facebook page, 24 Apr 2018)'), ('Languages', 'English'), ('Highlights', 'RankEventYearLocationResultWorld ChampionshipsHeats5000m2017London, GBR13:35.69World Cross Country Championships74Individual Cross Country Long Distance2015Guiyang, CHN39:23Asian Championships15000m2017Bhubaneswar, IND14:54.48110,000m2017Bhubaneswar, IND29:55.87210,000m2015Wuhan, CHN29:42.8135000m2015Wuhan, CHN13:36.6245000m2013Pune, IND14:17.01510,000m2013Pune, IND30:46.45')]

name: Vijayakumari
bio: [('Beginning', 'She took up the sport in 2012. (deccanherald.com, 18 Mar 2018)'), ('Reason', 'Coach YS Lakshmeesha selected her at the Sports Authority of India [SAI] trials in 2012. "My physical education teacher Mahalinge Gowda was very supportive. He took me to SAI selection trials in 2012 and I got selected. My coach [Lakshmeesha] spoke to my parents and tried convincing them that I had a future in running. After a lot of persuading, they finally agreed and I began training under him." (deccanherald.com, 18 Mar 2018)'), ('Debut', '2017 for India, Asian Championships in Bhubaneswar, India (deccanherald.com, 18 Mar 2018)'), ('Coach', 'YS Lakshmeesha [personal], IND (deccanherald.com, 18 Mar 2018)'), ('Additional Information', 'GeneralOCCUPATIONShe joined the Income Tax department of Chennai, India, under a sports quota programme that allows her to train and compete internationally. (deccanherald.com, 18 Mar 2018)EARLY DAYSHer parents were initially against her sporting career, and instead encouraged her to get married at age 16. However, her coach YS Lakshmeesha convinced her parents to allow her to pursue a career in athletics. "At the age of 16, my family wanted me to get married. Like many young girls in my village, my grandmother wanted me to marry and my parents were of the same opinion. Somewhere in their mind, the fact that I am still not married troubles them. But they have changed a lot and they are happy with whatever I have done. Even the people in my village look at me with a lot of respect." (deccanherald.com, 18 Mar 2018) '), ('Hero', 'Indian sprinter PT Usha, US sprinter Allyson Felix. (deccanherald.com, 18 March 2018)'), ('Education', 'Commerce - Arunodaya Evening College, Bengaluru, IND'), ('Languages', 'English, Hindi')]

name: Purnima
bio: [('Beginning', 'She enjoyed running when she was younger, and in 2011 she attended the Sports Authority of India [SAI] athletics trials. (sportskeeda.com, 18 Sep 2017)'), ('Reason', '"I used to run with other boys in my village and always beat them. Hence, my parents and village elders banned me from running with them. All I wanted was to run, so I went for the first Sports Authority of India [SAI] trials. When they took them, I didn\'t even know who I was trialling for. All I knew was that if I trialled, I would have a better life than I already had." (sportskeeda.com, 18 Sep 2017)'), ('Coach', 'Sanjay Garanayak, IND (archive.kiit.ac.in, 29 May 2017)'), ('Memorable', 'Winning gold in pentathlon at the 2017 Asian Indoor and Martial Arts Games in Ashgabat, Turkmenistan. (sportskeeda.com, 18 Sep 2017)'), ('Awards', "In 2018 she was named Outstanding Sportsperson of the Year by the Odisha Sports Journalists' Association [OSJA] in India. (orisports.com, 22 Mar 2018)She was named the 2015 Biju Patnaik Athlete of the Year in India. (orisports.com, 22 Mar 2018)She won the 2014 Ekalabya Award. The honour is presented by the government of Karnataka in India in recognition outstanding performance in sport. (orisports.com, 22 Mar 2018)"), ('Additional Information', 'GeneralSWITCHING DISCIPLINESHer career in athletics began as a sprinter before she moved on to heptathlon and pentathlon. "My coach just told me to keep doing what you\'re being asked to. When they asked me what I wanted to do after two years of training, I said whatever you want me to. I couldn\'t choose and so, they asked me to try heptathlon." (sportskeeda.com, 18 Sep 2017) '), ('Education', 'Kalinga Institute of Social Sciences, Bhubaneswar, IND'), ('Highlights', 'RankEventYearLocationResultAsian Championships3Heptathlon2017Bhubaneswar, IND57983Heptathlon2015Wuhan, CHN5511Commonwealth Games7Heptathlon2018Gold Coast, QLD, AUS5834')]

name: Dipa
bio: [('Beginning', 'She took up gymnastics at age six at the Netaji Subhas Regional Centre of the Sports Authority of India [SAI]. (sportscelebfamily.com, 26 Mar 2017; indianexpress.com, 18 Apr 2016)'), ('Reason', 'Her father worked as a coach at the Sports Authority of India [SAI] and encouraged her to try gymnastics. "Having watched gymnastics from up close, he knew more than anyone else that it wasn\'t just about dainty movements and pretty costumes. It needed strength and guts." (indianexpress.com, 18 Apr 2016)'), ('Coach', 'Bishweshwar Nandi [personal], IND (outlookindia.com, 14 Feb 2018)'), ('Training', 'She trains at the Indira Gandhi Stadium in Delhi, India. (thefield.scroll.in, 24 Aug 2017)'), ('Ambition', 'To win a medal at the 2018 Asian Games in Indonesia. (indiatimes.com, 28 Feb 2018)'), ('Awards', "In April 2017 she featured in Forbes Magazine's '30 Under 30' Asia list, which celebrates the accomplishments of achievers who are under the age of 30. (hindustantimes.com, 17 Apr 2017)In 2017 she received the Padma Shri Award in India. (Facebook page, 08 Mar 2018; business-standard.com, 13 Apr 2017) In January 2017 she became only the second Indian athlete to feature on a postage stamp issued by the Department of Post in India. She received the honour after becoming the first female gymnast from India to compete at the Olympic Games at the 2016 Games in Rio de Janeiro. (hindustantimes.com, 21 Jan 2017)In 2016 she received the Rajiv Gandhi Khel Ratna Award in India. (Facebook page, 08 Mar 2018; firstpost.com, 29 Aug 2016)She was presented with India's Arjuna Award in August 2015. (nelive.in, 30 Aug 2015)She was named the 2010 Gymnast of the Year by the Gymnastics Federation of India [GFI]. (gfi-gymnastics.in, 10 Apr 2010)"), ('Additional Information', 'GeneralNATIONAL FIRSTSShe became the first female gymnast representing India to compete at the Olympic Games when she participated at the 2016 Olympic Games in Rio de Janeiro. She was also the first female Indian gymnast to win a medal at the Commonwealth Games, claiming bronze on vault at the 2014 Games in Glasgow, Scotland. (SportsDeskOnline, 22 Jul 2018; news18.com, 25 Jan 2017; sportskeeda.com, 22 Feb 2016)PRODUNOVAOn her way to winning bronze on vault at the 2014 Commonwealth Games in Glasgow, Scotland, she became only the fifth female athlete to have landed the \'Produnova\'. The move, which is nicknamed the \'Vault of Death\', involves completing two somersaults before landing on the feet safely. "There can be death if you land on the neck, there\'s death if you go down headlong. It is risky, I know. But to win something, I always knew I had to take a risk. I\'d seen boys do it, so why not? It\'s tough because when you land after two aerial somersaults, the weight that comes on the leg is double - if I\'m 45kg, the legs have to take 80-90kg." (thequint.com, 13 Aug 2016; indianexpress.com, 18 Apr 2016) '), ('Relatives', 'Her father Dulal Karmakar has coached weightlifters for the Sports Authority of India [SAI]. (sportscelebfamily.com, 26 Mar 2017)'), ('Nickname', 'Guddu (dohagym.com, 08 Jan 2010)'), ('Injuries', 'She sustained a right knee injury during training at the 2018 Asian Games in Indonesia. The injury prevented her from competing in the team all-around final at the Games. She later competed in the balance beam final, although was still troubled by the injury. (firstpost.com, 22 Aug 2018; 24 Aug 2018; india.com, 24 Aug 2018)She suffered a knee injury at the Indian selection trials for the 2017 Asian Championships. She subsequently required surgery on her anterior cruciate ligament [ACL] in April 2017. (outlookindia.com, 14 Feb 2018; timesofindia.indiatimes.com, 22 Jun 2017)She suffered a hairline fracture of her ankle following the 2014 Commonwealth Games. Later in the year she was able to compete at the 2014 Asian Games in Incheon, Republic of Korea, with the aid of painkillers and a bandaged ankle. (newindianexpress.com, 25 Sep 2014)'), ('Education', "Humanities - Women's College, Agartala, India"), ('Languages', 'Bengali, English, Hindi'), ('Highlights', 'RankEventYearLocationResultAsian Games4Vault2014Incheon, KOR14.2008Team2014Incheon, KOR179.6258Vault2010Guangzhou, CHN13.40010Individual All-Around2014Incheon, KOR49.05020Balance Beam2014Incheon, KOR12.60026Floor Exercise2010Guangzhou, CHN10.90027Balance Beam2010Guangzhou, CHN11.70028Individual All-Around2010Guangzhou, CHN36.45032Uneven Bars2014Incheon, KOR10.15041Floor Exercise2014Incheon, KOR11.150Olympic Games4Vault2016Rio de Janeiro, BRA15.06651Individual All-Around2016Rio de Janeiro, BRA51.66565Balance Beam2016Rio de Janeiro, BRA12.86675Floor Exercise2016Rio de Janeiro, BRA12.03377Uneven Bars2016Rio de Janeiro, BRA11.666World Championships5Vault2015Glasgow, GBR14.68310Vault2014Nanning, CHN14.48318Vault2013Antwerp, BEL13.91621Vault2011Tokyo, JPN13.41632Vault2009London, GBR12.96238Team2014Nanning, CHN166.87861Floor Exercise2013Antwerp, BEL12.10063Individual All-Around2013Antwerp, BEL46.64891Uneven Bars2013Antwerp, BEL10.31697Balance Beam2013Antwerp, BEL10.366101Floor Exercise2009London, GBR10.425103Individual All-Around2015Glasgow, GBR49.966117Balance Beam2015Glasgow, GBR12.333120Individual All-Around2009London, GBR23.575135Floor Exercise2015Glasgow, GBR12.533162Balance Beam2011Tokyo, JPN11.266201Uneven Bars2015Glasgow, GBR10.000202Individual All-Around2011Tokyo, JPN24.699237Individual All-Around2014Nanning, CHN13.866Asian Championships3Vault2015Hiroshima, JPN14.7257Individual All-Around2015Hiroshima, JPN52.4008Balance Beam2015Hiroshima, JPN12.47510Uneven Bars2015Hiroshima, JPN12.15015Floor Exercise2015Hiroshima, JPN12.450Commonwealth Games3Vault2014Glasgow, GBR14.366')]

name: Gurjit
bio: [('Beginning', 'She took up hockey after moving to Kairon, India. In 2006 she started basic training with coach Sharanjeet Singh from Punjab Police in Kairon, India. (tribuneindia.com, 12 Nov 2017; tribuneindia.com, 06 Nov 2017)'), ('Debut', '2014 for India against Malaysia (Athlete, 17 Aug 2018)'), ('Ambition', 'To win a gold medal at the Olympic Games, and to become the best drag flicker in the world.. (jagbani.punjabkesari.in, 08 Nov 2017; Athlete, 17 Aug 2018)'), ('Memorable', 'Winning the 2017 Asia Cup. (Athlete, 17 Aug 2018)'), ('Additional Information', 'GeneralDEVELOPMENTShe was India\'s top scorer at the 2017 Asia Cup in Kakamigahara, Japan, finishing the competition with eight goals. She put her success down to changes she made to her drag-flicking technique after working with Dutch coach Toon Siepman ahead of the tournament. "With Siepman, I corrected the basics like keeping my head up, how to turn my body and the stepping during the drag-flicking process. These were minor changes, but I had never realised earlier that I was doing it incorrectly. He told me, \'Just make these small changes and you can become the best drag-flicker in the world\'. I keep that in mind every time I work on drag-flicking." (tribuneindia.com, 12 Nov 2017) '), ('Hero', 'Her father. (Athlete, 17 Aug 2018)'), ('Influence', 'Her father. (Athlete, 17 Aug 2018)'), ('Relatives', 'Her older sister Pradeep has played hockey at national level and worked as a coach for the Punjab Sports Department in India. (tribuneindia.com, 12 Nov 2017; tribuneindia.com, 06 Nov 2017)'), ('Nickname', 'Guri (Athlete, 17 Aug 2018)'), ('Education', 'Guru Nanak Dev University, Amritsar, IND'), ('Languages', 'English, Hindi, Punjabi'), ('Hobbies', 'Dancing. name: VIRDHAWAL VIKRAM
bio: [('Beginning', 'He began swimming at age four in Kolhapur, India. (Facebook page, 25 Apr 2018)'), ('Reason', 'His father, a former basketball player, talked him into trying swimming at the PGT pool near his home in Kolhapur, India. "My dad wanted me to concentrate on an individual event." (hindu.com, 14 Jul 2008; hinduonnet.com 11 Oct 2006)'), ('Coach', 'Nihar Ameen (thehindu.com, 24 Mar 2018)'), ('Training', 'He swims for six hours a day, before spending two hours in the gym. (firstpost.com, 23 Mar 2018)'), ('Ambition', 'To win two medals, including one gold, at the 2018 Asian Games in Indonesia, and to compete in an Olympic final. (news18.com, 13 Jun 2018; indiatimes.com, 29 Mar 2018; thehindu.com, 24 Mar 2018)'), ('Awards', "He was presented with India's Arjuna Award in 2011. (firstpost.com, 23 Mar 2018)"), ('Additional Information', 'GeneralWORKING LIFEIn around 2010 he began combining his swimming career with a full-time job as a public servant. His results suffered and he competed in the sport less until November 2017 when, following a number of different postings around India because of his work with the Indian government, he returned to Mumbai to live permanently. "I started taking time out for myself. I started training, swimming twice a day and going to the gym. I started with my food; I started watching what I ate. That played a big role in helping me get back in shape. I worked very hard in the gym. The one place that I think I earlier lacked was that I was weaker than my competitors abroad. I got a lot stronger than what I used to be." (firstpost.com, 23 Mar 2018) '), ('Nickname', 'Veer [Brave]. (virdhawal.blogspot.com, 19 Feb 2008)'), ('Injuries', 'He missed half of the 2007 season due to a combination of illness and study commitments. name: Irfan
bio: [('Beginning', 'He took up race walking in 2006 in Kerala, India. (thehindu.com, 07 Sep 2012)'), ('Reason', '"There was one walker in my village named Ribas. He was considered the best walker in Kerala. I used to serve refreshments to Ribas and sometimes note his training times. One day, some of my friends suggested I try race walking when I accompany Ribas. I tried it for a few days and started liking it. That was the turning point in my life." (sportskeeda.com, 29 May 2014)'), ('Coach', 'Alexander Artsybashev [national], RUS (indianexpress.com, 17 Feb 2018)'), ('Memorable', 'Finishing 10th in the 20km walk at the 2012 Olympic Games in London. (sportskeeda.com, 05 Mar 2016)'), ('Additional Information', 'GeneralOCCUPATIONHe joined the Indian Army under a sports quota programme that allows him to train and compete internationally. (Facebook profile, 07 Apr 2018; olympic.ind.in, 05 Apr 2018)COMMONWEALTH EXITHe was sent home from the 2018 Commonwealth Games in Gold Coast, QLD, Australia, after needles were found in his room, violating the Games\' \'no needle\' policy. The Athletics Federation of India [AFI] gave him a warning after no anti-doping violation was found. (hindustantimes.com, 02 May 2018; thehindu.com, 16 Apr 2018)LONDON BREAKTHROUGHHe finished 10th in the 20km race walk at the 2012 Olympic Games in London. "Generally people end their career with the Olympics but for me it was different as I started my career with it. I had no expectations but giving my best out there. My father works on the field and my mother is a housewife. We have land and amenities, but before the Olympics I had absolutely nothing, so getting the basics such as professional equipment was difficult. Since my Olympic participation a lot of things have changed on a positive note for race walking in India." (sportskeeda.com, 05 Mar 2016)OTHER STUDIESHe has also studied economics at Devagiri College in Calicut, India. (Facebook profile, 07 Apr 2018) '), ('Nickname', 'KT, Malappuram Express (sportskeeda.com, 29 May 2014)'), ('Injuries', 'In 2014 he sustained a stress fracture to his right ankle. He was able to compete at the 2014 Asian Games in Incheon, Republic of Korea, but after the event required further treatment. He did not return to training until October 2015. (indianexpress.com, 27 Feb 2016; scroll.in, 19 Feb 2018)'), ('Education', 'Economics - University of Calicut, India'), ('Languages', 'English, Hindi, Malayalam'), ('Highlights', 'RankEventYearLocationResultAsian Games520km Walk2014Incheon, KOR1:23:18Olympic Games1020km Walk2012London, GBR1:20:21World Championships2320km Walk2017London, GBR1:21:40DSQ20km Walk2013Moscow, RUSDSQCommonwealth Games1320km Walk2018Gold Coast, QLD, AUS1:27:34World Race Walking Challenge320km Walk2017Nomi, JPN1:20:59')]

name: RAVI
bio: [('Beginning', 'He began practising shooting in 2007. (timesofindia.indiatimes.com, 06 Mar 2018)'), ('Reason', "He got inspiration to take up the sport from his mother's uncle Rajpal Singh and his son Vivek Singh. (timesofindia.indiatimes.com, 06 Mar 2018)"), ('Coach', 'Oleg Mikhailov [national], UKR; Kanwar Randhir Singh [national], IND (sportsauthorityofindia.nic.in, 13 Feb 2018)'), ('Ambition', 'To win a medal at the Olympic Games. (results.gc2018.com, 01 Jan 2018)'), ('Additional Information', 'GeneralMOTIVATIONAfter suffering an injury just prior to the 2016 Olympic Games in Rio de Janeiro, he approached former Indian shooter Abhinav Bindra, who facilitated his rehabilitation at his medical centre in Mohali, India. He not only helped him recover from the injury, but also worked with him to improve his technique. "He is a perfectionist and wants others to be like him. I was not that much disciplined when I went to him. But after working with him for some time, I felt I need to do better. Eat on time, eat what\'s needed, sleep on time and train hard. Really hard. He would always say there was no point in thinking about Olympics if you were not willing to work hard. No point in dreaming if you are not hungry enough." (newindianexpress.com, 20 Dec 2017)OCCUPATIONHe joined the Indian Air Force under a sports quota programme that allows him to train and compete internationally. (sportstarlive.com, 20 Dec 2017; timesofindia.indiatimes.com, 20 Dec 2017) '), ('Hero', 'Indian cricketer Yuvraj Singh. (results.gc2018.com, 01 Jan 2018)'), ('Injuries', 'While training for the 2016 Olympic Games in Rio de Janeiro, he started feeling pain in his left shoulder. The pain spread to his back and his spinal cord lost some curvature. He missed the Olympic Games and remained out of action for 14 months. (newindianexpress.com, 20 Dec 2017)'), ('Languages', 'English, Hindi'), ('Hobbies', 'Driving. (results.gc2018.com, 01 Jan 2018)'), ('Highlights', 'RankEventYearLocationResultAsian Games310m Air Rifle Team Men2014Incheon, KOR1863.02010m Air Rifle2014Incheon, KOR618.9World Championships7810m Air Rifle2014Granada, ESP616.2World Cup Final810m Air Rifle2017New Delhi, IND123.4World Cup310m Air Rifle2018Guadalajara, MEX226.4410m Air Rifle2018Changwon, KOR208.4410m Air Rifle Mixed Team2018Guadalajara, MEX392.6510m Air Rifle Mixed Team2018Changwon, KOR351.0510m Air Rifle2017Munich, GER185.7810m Air Rifle2017New Delhi, IND122.01110m Air Rifle Mixed Team2018Munich, GER836.81310m Air Rifle2018Munich, GER628.64110m Air Rifle2017Qabala, AZE620.0Asian Championships310m Air Rifle2017Wako, JPN225.7610m Air Rifle2014Kuwait City, KUW119.6810m Air Rifle2013Tehran, IRI79.8Commonwealth Games310m Air Rifle2018Gold Coast, QLD, AUS224.1World Ranking (as of 01 Aug 2018)510m Air Rifle2018805')]

name: SUSHIL
bio: [('Beginning', "He took up wrestling at age 14 at the Chhatrasal Stadium's wrestling school in India. (BBC, 06 Apr 2012)"), ('Reason', 'His cousin Sandeep and his father were both wrestlers. (wrestlersushilkumar.com, 19 Dec 2017)'), ('Debut', '2003 for India, Asian Championships in New Delhi, India (fila-wrestling.com, 30 Jul 2010)'), ('Coach', 'Jagminder Singh [national], IND; Vladimir Mestvirishvili [personal], GEO; Satpal Singh [personal, father-in-law], IND (hindustantimes.com, 28 Apr 2018; indiatimes.com, 19 Oct 2017)'), ('Ambition', 'To win a third medal at the Olympic Games. (firstpost.com, 03 Apr 2018)'), ('Awards', "He was presented with the Padam Shri Award in 2011. (Facebook page, 23 Jul 2014)In 2009 he was a joint winner of the Rajiv Gandhi Khel Ratna award, which is India's highest honour for sportsmen. (blog.taragana.com, 01 Sep 2010)He won an Arjuna Award for 2006, India's second highest national sports award. (hindu.com, 18 Aug 2006)"), ('Additional Information', 'GeneralNATIONAL FIRSTSHe became the first freestyle wrestler representing India to win three gold medals at the Commonwealth Games by claiming victory in the 74kg category at the 2018 Games in Gold Coast, QLD, Australia. He had previously won gold medals in the 66kg category at the 2010 Games in Delhi, India, and in the 74kg category at the 2014 Games in Glasgow, Scotland. He became the first Indian wrestler to win gold at the world championships when he claimed victory in the 66kg category at the 2010 edition in Moscow, Russian Federation. (espn.in, 12 Apr 2018; indiatimes.com, 12 Aug 2012; BBC, 06 Apr 2012; SportsDeskOnline, 29 Jul 2018)EARLY DAYSHe was inspired to take up wrestling by his father. "[He] was a fantastic wrestler but he gave up a promising career to work on the buses so that he could provide for our family. I remember when I first joined the academy at the Chhatrasal Stadium, I had to sleep in a dormitory with 20 other wrestlers. We didn\'t have much money so my parents brought me tinned milk, ghee and vegetables as I\'m a strict vegetarian." (BBC, 06 Apr 2012)OCCUPATIONHe joined the Indian Railways under a sports quota programme that allows him to train and compete internationally. (Facebook profile, 22 Dec 2017; pib.nic.in, 20 Dec 2017) '), ('Injuries', "He suffered a knee injury that ruled him out of the 2018 Asian Championships in Bishkek, Kyrgyzstan. name: DEEPIKA
bio: [('Beginning', 'She took up the sport in Kharsawan, India, before moving to the Tata Archery Academy in 2008. (hindustantimes.com, 11 Oct 2010; telegraphindia.com, 30 Sep 2013)'), ('Reason', 'Her cousin was an archer and encouraged her to take up the sport, with the support of her mother. "As per my mother\'s memories I never used to miss my target while aiming for mangoes with stones during childhood, and that\'s why she motivated me in every step of attaining my dreams. Initially my father was a little sceptical about it, but my cousin Vidya who was already an archer at Tata Archery Academy, showed the way." (Facebook page, 23 Apr 2018)'), ('Debut', '2010 for India, World Cup in Antalya, Turkey (worldarchery.org, 01 Oct 2008)'), ('Coach', 'Jiwanjot Singh Teja [national], IND; Dhaneshwar Maida [national], IND (tribuneindia.com, 29 Nov 2017)'), ('Training', 'She began spending more time in the gym in 2015 after increasing the draw weight of her bow to 42lbs. (hindustantimes.com, 29 Jul 2015)'), ('Ambition', 'To compete at the Olympic Games in 2020 and 2024, and become the first Indian to win an Olympic gold medal. Outside of competition she hopes to open a sports academy one day, and help in the fight for equal rights for women in India. (indianexpress.com, 10 Mar 2018; inews.co.uk, 07 Mar 2018)'), ('Awards', 'In September 2017 she received the Young Achievers Award from Vogue, a fashion and lifestyle magazine. (hindustantimes.com, 26 Sep 2017)In January 2016 she was presented with a Padma Shri Award, the fourth-highest civilian award in India, for services to archery. (hindustantimes.com, 26 Jan 2016) In March 2014 she was named Sportsperson of the Year in India by her employer Tata Steel. (timesofindia.indiatimes.com, 03 Mar 2014)In February 2014 she was named the Sportsperson of the Year at the India Sports Awards by the Federation of Indian Chambers of Commerce & Industry [FICCI], an association of business organisations in India. (news.biharprabha.com, 13 Feb 2014)She won an Arjuna Award in India in 2012. (timesofindia.indiatimes.com, 01 Nov 2013; deepikakumari.com, 04 Apr 2013)'), ('Additional Information', 'Draw weight42lbs (hindustantimes.com, 29 Jul 2015)GeneralEARLY DAYSAs a child, she would spend her holidays at her grandmother\'s place, where she came in contact with her cousin Vidya Kumari, who told her about her involvement with archery at the Tata Archery Academy in Jharkhand, India. Inspired by her cousin, she visited the academy to enrol. Enrolling in the academy also meant that she would get regular meals, as she came from a poor financial background and was malnourished. She says her life changed as she began receiving formal training at the academy. "I didn\'t even know what archery was at first. I was just a girl in search of food and shelter. I\'m the eldest of our family and I thought if I left home and provided for myself, it would be one less mouth for my family to have to feed. My mum and dad, on the other hand, argued I was too young to live by myself, and that sports was unreliable as a career, and I should focus on studies. I would argue with them that I need to go, I stayed adamant until they relented. At Tata, I started competing more, got better coaches and training, and life also got better as there were proper food and living conditions. Watching my seniors there, who had won various competitions, I would get inspired and motivated to win too." (yourstory.com, 23 Mar 2018; inews.co.uk, 07 Mar 2018; timesofindia.indiatimes.com, 08 Mar 2018)OCCUPATIONShe joined Tata Steel under a sports quota programme that allows her to train and compete internationally. (Facebook page, 23 Apr 2018; worldarcherycentre.org, 02 Mar 2018)DOCUMENTARYIn 2017, a 39-minute documentary film titled \'Ladies First\' depicted her life story, from childhood to becoming a top archer. "I am excited that around one hundred and fifty countries will see my story. The documentary talks about my life as an archer for sure, but it also shows many other shades of my life. It is a story of things we want to do and can\'t do. Things we do and the struggle surrounding it. It gives a sneak peek into the sports world of our country, and how the government has its own agenda and not necessarily conducive to the sportsmen. We work really hard. We have plans too, but that doesn\'t always resonate with the authorities. They don\'t work in tandem. They don\'t discuss things with us. Most of the times players feel that things are done half-heartedly from their side." (yourstory.com, 23 Mar 2018; indianexpress.com, 10 Mar 2018)MOVIEIn 2018 she was chosen to play the lead role in a movie titled \'Bisahi\', which aims at raising awareness about the practice of witch hunting. The film is set in her home state, Jharkhand, India. (hindustantimes.com, 16 Jan 2018)JUNIOR HISTORY MAKERShe became the second archer from India [after Palton Hansda in 2006] and first female to win a world junior title when she won gold in the compound individual event at the 2009 World Youth Championships in Ogden, UT, United States of America. (indiansportswomen.org, 07 Sep 2011) '), ('Hero', 'Indian archers Jayanta Talukdar and Dola Banerjee. (tribuneindia.com, 05 Dec 2009)'), ('Relatives', 'Her cousin Vidya has also attended the Tata Archery Academy in India. (telegraphindia.com, 30 Sep 2013)'), ('Nickname', 'Deepa (World Archery, 16 Jul 2012)'), ('Injuries', 'She suffered a shoulder injury prior to the 2016 Olympic Games in Rio de Janeiro. However, she participated in the event despite the injury. (inews.co.uk, 07 Mar 2018)She suffered a wrist injury in March 2014. (indianexpress.com, 31 Mar 2014)'), ('Education', 'KMCT College, India'), ('Languages', 'English, Hindi'), ('Hobbies', 'Music and food. (World Archery, 16 Jul 2012, 25 Oct 2015)'), ('Highlights', "RankEventYearLocationAsian Games3Recurve Women's Team2010Guangzhou, CHN4Recurve Women's Team2014Incheon, KOR4Recurve name: Suriya
bio: [('Beginning', 'She began running at Kavinadu Youth Sports Club in Pudukkottai, India. (espn.co.uk, 02 Jun 2017)'), ('Reason', 'She got involved in the sport because her father was a coach. She began taking athletics more seriously after she started winning local school competitions. (hindustantimes.com, 18 Feb 2016)'), ('Coach', 'Surendra Singh [national], IND (timesofindia.indiatimes.com, 08 Mar 2018)'), ('Additional Information', 'GeneralFAMILY AFFAIRHer brother Govindan Lakshmanan was adopted by her family at age six after his father passed away in an accident. Although Suriya has been running for most of her life, Govindan only became interested at about age 14 because his sister was spending so much time at the track. The two now spend a significant amount of time together at national training camps, and both say they find being around a sibling is helpful. "A lot of the campers have told me that when they see us fight and joke with each other, they tell me how much they miss their own brothers. A lot of them are lonely so it makes me appreciate how special it is to have my brother in the national camp with me," Suriya said. (espn.co.uk, 02 Jun 2017) '), ('Relatives', 'Her adopted brother Govindan Lakshmanan has represented India in athletics, winning gold in the 5000m and 10,000m at the 2017 Asian Athletics Championships in Bhubaneswar, India. Her father S. Loganathan was a distance runner and is founder of the Kavinadu Youth Sports Club in Pudukkottai, India. (newindianexpress.com, 17 Jul 2017; espn.co.uk, 02 Jun 2017; hindustantimes.com, 18 Feb 2016)'), ('Injuries', 'She missed three months of the 2016 season due to a knee injury. (timesofindia.indiatimes.com, 08 Mar 2018)'), ('Highlights', 'RankEventYearLocationResultAsian Championships45000m2017Bhubaneswar, IND16:01.96410,000m2017Bhubaneswar, IND33:04.10710,000m2013Pune, IND34:43.63South Asian Games15000m2016India15:45.75110,000m2016India32:39.86Commonwealth Games1310,000m2018Gold Coast, QLD, AUS32:23.56')]
